metadata.case_name: C. L. Subramaniam v. Collector of Customs

facts.text: Appellant was Preventive Officer, Grade II, Customs Office, Cochin from June 16, 1962 to January 31, 1963.
In April 1962, appellant applied to Assistant Collector of Customs for permission for his wife to run taxi service; informed permission not necessary but should not canvass business for wife.
Appellant, acting on behalf of wife, purchased cars used as taxis.
Several complaints against appellant that he canvassed business for his wife; complaints enquired into.
On March 25, 1963, memorandum served stating appellant contravened rule 12(1) of Central Civil Services Conduct Rules, 1955 by canvassing business for wife; enquiry to be held.
Sri H. T. Soares, Assistant Collector, appointed Enquiry Officer.
During pendency of enquiry, additional ground served: appellant himself running taxi service.
Enquiry Officer concluded allegations established, guilty of contravening rule 12(1); recommended removal from service.
Disciplinary Authority served notice to show cause why not removed; appellant's explanation not accepted; ordered removed from service.
Appellant filed writ petition under Art. 226 before Kerala High Court; dismissed by single judge; affirmed by Division Bench on March 26, 1970.
In September 1963, A. M. Shivaraman (trained police prosecutor) appointed to present case in support of charges.
Appellant wrote on October 4, 1963 to Collector requesting permission to engage counsel as Shivaraman legally trained.
Appellant reiterated request on October 9 and 14, 1963.
On October 17, 1963, Assistant Collector (on behalf of Collector) refused permission stating Shivaraman not legal practitioner, no necessity.
On January 6, 1964, appellant wrote explaining difficulties, requested counsel due to nature of accusations, witnesses, etc.
Appellant requested assistance of Abraham Kurian, clerk, Cochin Head Post Office, before December 5, 1963 enquiry date; requested Disciplinary Authority to get permission from superiors.
Disciplinary Authority wrote to Superintendent of Post Offices, Trichur on November 28, 1963; not received in time.
On December 4, 1963, appellant requested 10-day adjournment as Kurian awaiting permission.
Enquiry on December 5, 1963 adjourned sine die; appellant undertook to proceed without assistance if needed next time.
On December 9, 1963, appellant wrote to Enquiry Officer requesting timely notice to Superintendent for Kurian's permission.
Enquiry Officer fixed January 8, 1964; wrote to Superintendent on December 30, 1963; Kurian did not get permission.
Enquiry proceeded without appellant's assistance.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellant afforded reasonable opportunity under Art. 311, specifically compliance with sub-rule 5 of rule 15 CCS(CCA) Rules 1957 regarding permission for legal practitioner and assistance of government servant.

petitioner_arguments.text: Denied permission to engage counsel despite facing trained prosecutor (Shivaraman); circumstances warranted permission under rule 15(5).
Denied assistance of Abraham Kurian due to Enquiry Officer's delay in obtaining permission from superiors.
Right to engage lawyer as agent, citing Pet v. Greyhound Racing Association Ltd.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Pet v. Greyhound Racing Association Ltd.

respondent_arguments.text: No necessity for lawyer as Shivaraman not legal practitioner.
No right to legal practitioner or union representative in domestic enquiries per precedents.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Kalindi v. Tata Locomotive; Brooke Bond v. Subba Raman; Dunlop Rubber v. Workmen

court_reasoning.text: Disciplinary Authority failed to consider circumstances (trained prosecutor) for permitting counsel; brushed aside request on irrelevant ground.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fact that case handled by trained prosecutor good ground for allowing counsel lest scales weighted against appellant.

court_reasoning.text: Enquiry Officer failed to facilitate assistance of Abraham Kurian by timely communication to superiors; deprived appellant of entitled assistance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Indifferent attitude of Enquiry Officer breached rule 15(5).

court_reasoning.text: Pet case distinguished as no statutory rule there; agency theory irrelevant under statutory prohibition.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Labour cases on natural justice not applicable to Art. 311 or statutory rule scope.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 15(5) mandatory, regulates Art. 311 guarantee; govt servants lack legal training, serious consequences warrant representation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Breach caused prejudice, denied reasonable opportunity.

holdings.text: Impugned removal order struck down for contravention of rule 15(5); no reasonable opportunity under Art. 311.
No fresh enquiry; restore appellant to position entitled but for impugned order.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pet v. Greyhound Racing Association Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Agency theory for legal representation under natural justice; not applicable to statutory rule prohibiting lawyer except in permitted circumstances.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kalindi and ors. v. Tata Locomotive and Engineering Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: No right to union representative in management enquiry under natural justice.

precedents_cited.case_name: Brooke Bond India (P) Ltd. v. Subba Raman
precedents_cited.relevance: No right to representation by another in domestic enquiries.
Reiterated no right to representation in domestic tribunals.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petition under 226; pleasure doctrine subject to 311 reasonable opportunity; rules under 309.

statutes_cited.name: Central Civil Services (Conduct) Rules, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Charge of contravention by canvassing business.

statutes_cited.name: Central Civil Services (Classification, Control and Appeal) Rules, 1957
statutes_cited.relevance: Procedure for major penalty; right to assistance by govt servant or lawyer if permitted considering circumstances.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; impugned removal order struck down for breach of rule 15(5) denying reasonable opportunity; no fresh enquiry directed; appellant restored to position entitled but for the order.

key_quotes.text: The fact that the case against the appellant was being handled by a trained prosecutor was a good ground for allowing the appellant to engage a legal practitioner to defend him lest the scales should be weighted against him.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reason for finding failure to exercise discretion under rule 15(5).

key_quotes.text: From the facts set out above, it is clear that the Enquiry Officer did not afford the appellant necessary facility to have the assistance of another Government servant in defending him which assistance he was entitled to under the rule.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Finding of breach due to procedural lapses in facilitating assistance.

key_quotes.text: We are also of the opinion that the appellant had not been afforded a reasonable opportunity to defend himself. Hence the impugned order is liable to be struck down and it is hereby struck down.
key_quotes.speaker: court
